climbs.name: Cave Fever
climbs.fa: Colin Bell, Gilles LaCroix and Fred Doucette 1978.

content.description:
Start on a crack riddled slab below an obvious large chimney/cave. Climb the slab to a steep crack with good finger locks and hand jams. Gain a sloping ledge that leads to the back of the cave. Follow the weakness in the back of the cave moving up and right. Wild stemming will take you to a stance below a juggy overhanging section. Follow this up to lower angled wide cracks that lead to a bolted anchor. 

History: This route was originally climbed back in 1978 as an ice climb by Colin Bell and company. In August of 2020 after a long dry period this usually wet route was climbed by Greg Hughes and Dom Caron using only rock gear for protection. 



Move up the scree field past the nose approaching the back wall of Pooh Corner. Cave Fever is the impossible to miss feature on the left wall. 

Standard rack to 3 or 4. Long runners are absolutely esential to reduce rope drag. Maybe double up on .75 to 2. Bolted anchor. Rap the route. You can get down with a 60 meter rope but a few feet of easy down climbing may be required. Tie knots!

climbs.name: Grandpa's Demise
climbs.fa: P. Lloyd, S. Adamson, J. Wildenburg 1992

content.description:
Climb up the short corner past a few bolts to gain the slab. Follow the slabby corner until you are about 5m from the rap station. Break off right on the steeper wall at a small left facing corner. Very nice climbing relatively straight up this wall with gear and bolts take you to a rap station at the top of the wall.



Starts in the corner at the back of Pooh corner area.

a few bolts. standard rack. rap rings

Very fun climb with pretty unique movement.

Same Start as Tigger Patrol. Make a reach to a good horizontal jug. Climb up short vertical crack into nice juggy horizontals under the roof. Traverse left under the roof (crux) to the arête and pull onto the slab above. Move straight up into a vertical crack. When it ends, follow easy climbing up and right to rap rings on a ledge (30m)

Pitch 2 - move up and left from the anchor then right through an overlap to gain a left facing corner ramp that will lead to the top of the cliff. 5.7 G 30 meters.



Near the corner at the back of Pooh Corner. Shares a start a few metres downhill and left of the corner. Shares the start with Tigger Patrol.

Standard rack.

Climb up slanting features off the ground to a good break under the roof (multiple betas possible). Clip a bolt and sort out a tricky crux. The climbing eases as you continue up the face with several horizontals to gain a sloping ledge. Step onto the left side of the blunt arête and clip a second bolt (alpine draw recommended to reduce rope drag). Make your way up and right to the crack splitting the lip, pull the lip and finish as for Sweet Marie up the slabby cracks.


2 bolts. Standard rack to BD #2

climbs.name: Hundred Acre Crack
climbs.fa: P. Adamson, S. Jones, L. Perrin 2021

content.description:
Climb up the corner shared with Grandpa's Demise and Honey Pot past 3 bolts. Continue straight up, placing a BD #2 in a diagonal crack then clipping the bolt above. From here, follow the diagonal crack up and right past bolts. Fun movement on slopers and pods eventually lead to a slab where the climbing eases. Finish on the same rap ring anchor as Piglet's Big Adventure.



Starts in the corner at the back left of Pooh Corner. Shared start with Grandpa's Demise and Honey Pot.

bolts and a single BD #2 between the 3rd and 4th bolts. Rap rings.

This is a 2nd pitch. Access by climbing the first pitch of Snot.

A wild and exposed climb up Pooh Corner's most prominent feature - the nose. From the rap station at the top of Snot pitch 1, head up and right into a horizontal crack. Traverse right to the base of the nose. Rest up then fire through a tough boulder problem on slopers heading for the tip of the nose (2 bolts). Mantle over and follow the bridge of the nose (easy PG climbing) to the anchor.



This route climbs the left side of the prominent nose feature (when looking at it from the ground). To access, climb the first pitch of Snot.

Standard rack to BD #1. Doubles are nice to have. Rap ring anchor.

Climb up Sinus. After the questionable blocks, move right under the roof on a couple jugs, clip a bolt and pull a fun boulder problem. Continue up cracks to the top.



Climbs the first 3/4 of Sinus.

Standard rack to BD #4. Rap ring anchor.

This is a second pitch. Start from the belay at the top of the first pitch of Snot or Psychic Hotline.

Climb the hand crack in a left facing corner behind the tree (same as Psychic Hotline). Follow the corner all the way to the roof and traverse right under the roof then straight up to some trees.

**Note at the time of writing (August 2021) there are some sketchy loose blocks under the roof. Also the rock quality in the roof is bad



This is a second pitch. To access, either climb the first pitch of Snot or Psychic Hotline.

Standard rack. Tree anchor

Pitch 1: Start by the large chair stump and climb easily up a few metres to a short left-facing corner with an old piton. Move up this corner and into a finger crack. Continue up lower angled easy climbing and belay either at rap station or tree a few metres higher (5.9, 30m)

Pitch 2: Climb up a hand crack in a left facing corner behind the tree for about 5m. Reach right and clip a bolt. Leave the corner and move onto the arête. Follow it past 2 more bolts. (5.9 20m).



From Cheekbone Corner, walk uphill around and around a corner to a more east-facing cliff. This is the furthest left route on that wall and climbs just right of the arête of Granite Planet. There is a large stump carved into a chair at the base of this route.

Doubles in finger sized pieces. A few small cams.

Start either by Weeping Whisker or a few metres right on a short steep chunky section of rock. Continue up  past some ledges to a large flake. Move slightly left into a section of questionable blocks. Continue up and left skirting around roofs. 



Starts a few metres right and uphill from the very tall pine tree.

Standard rack to #4 BD cam.

Start up the gully and move left after about 5m. Continue up the somewhat exposed arete making multiple mantles over bulges. As the terrain eases, aim for a tree at the top of the slab.



Scramble up the loose trail to reach the far right of pooh corner. This route climbed the arete hidden in the corner.

Std rack, doubles in small/medium sizes may be helpful

P1: Climb up flakes and cracks, following the path of least resistance to a small ledge with rap station a few metres below a tree. 30m

P2: Move up on slanting ledge and climb a zig-zagging fist crack just right of a chimney. At the top, move left into the chimney. 25m



Starts below and slightly left of the prominent nose feature, a few metres down from the tall pine tree. The start of this route is currently marked by a tree stump shaped like a chair.

Standard rack to BD #4

climbs.name: Sweet Marie
climbs.fa: Tom Anderson, J and C Daigle 1999

content.description:
Easily one of the best routes at the cliff. Great jamming, movement and exposure. The guide book says two pitches but it can easily be climbed in one. Start up pleasant features below the hand/fist crack. Ascend the crack until it is possible to traverse left under an overhang. Move up to a small stance (optional belay) then continue moving up and left towards a notch. Go through the notch to a glorious hand crack that will take you to the top of the pitch. There is a perfectly positioned pine tree for the belay. Despite the length of the route a 70 rope will get you back down to the ground with a bit of stretch. Tie knots!



Just left of Cave Fever there is a hand/fist crack about 5 meters off the deck. The climb starts just below this crack. 

Standard rack to 4 inch piece. Double 2 and 3 would be wise or climb in two pitches. Tree anchor. Rap the route.

Make a reach to a good horizontal. Climb up a short vertical crack into nice juggy horizontals under the roof. Pull straight through the roof into a slightly flaring hand crack above. Continue up the easy slab, trending right to rap rings on a ledge in the corner. (30m)

If desired, from the rap station continue up the slabby left facing corner to the top of the cliff (50m total)



Near the corner at the back of Pooh Corner. Shares a start a few metres downhill and left of the corner. Shares the start withHang Ten.

Standard rack. Rap rings

Classic! This route climbs the right side of the prominent nose feature at Pooh Corner.

Start near the base of a large pine and make your way up some cracks to a ledge. Move left slightly and climb a left facing corner. At its top, step right into another, smaller left facing corner. Funky climbing up this smaller corner/arête takes you to a pink jug. Be sure to extend some gear and traverse horizontally left to the base of the nose feature (a hand traverse is the traditional beta but a foot traverse is also possible). Climb up the finger crack in the corner formed by the nose then top out on the slab.

Strategically extending gear on this pitch is paramount.



Near the left edge of Pooh corner, starts directly at the base of a very large pine tree.

Standard rack. some doubles are nice to have. Rap ring anchor.

Tucked away between Cheekbone and Waterfall Wall is Pooh Corner. Facing east it gets early sun and goes into the shade in early afternoon. The classic Weeping Whisker is here along with Sinus and Snot.
